prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 1.3mm Spectral Setup
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Based on the Cycle 0 setup of Zhang et al. (2015), this setup observes prominant lines (DCO+, N2D+, DCN, C18O, CO, SiO, etc.) at 0.8 km/s resolution and the lines of H2CO at 0.4 km/s resolution with over 4 GHz of continuum bandwidth. Differences between this setup and the Zhang setup include - (1) we use a higher spectral resolution windows in the second baseband (2) we employ dual polarization since our spectral windows are more targeted to achieve better sensitivity of the main spectral lines of interest.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This is a modification of the successful cycle 0 setup used by Zhang et al. (2015) to observe fragmentation in the G28.34 clump. All spectra windows except those centered on H2CO lines in the baseband 2, have 0.7 - 0.8 km/s resolution which should be sufficient to resolve ~2-4 km/s lines observed toward the starless clumps with single dish telescopes (i.e. NH3 (1,1) with the GBT). The single dish observations indicate that these massive starless clump candidates are still very turbulent. For baseband 2, we have selected spectral windows with a factor of 2 better spectral resolution in case narrower than expected lines are observed toward these sources. The H2CO 3_0,3 - 2_0,2 transition was consistently the strongest dense gas line observed towards cores in Zhang et al. (2015); therefore we select this line for higher spectral resolution.
We have decide to employ dual polarization and specific targeted spectral windows to provide more flexibility in the spectral line setup compared to the original Zhang et al. (2015) setup. The spectral windows in the four basebands are characterized as follows:
Baseband1 centers 2 spectral windows with 0.8 km/s resolution on the lines of DCO+ 3-2 and SiO 5-4. The second spectral window also contains the DCN 3-2 transition mentioned in the science case.
Baseband2 centers 3 spectral windows on H2CO transition at 0.4 km/s resolution (the first spectral window is expected to contain the strongest transition). A low energy transition of CH3OH is also within these spectral windows. The fourth spectral window is centered on C18O 2-1. We do not discuss this transition in the science case as the emission is likely very extended and this molecule can freezeout in cold, dense region (it is not an optimum core tracer). We obtain these observations "for free".
Baseband3 centers 2 spectral windows with 0.8 km/s resolution on CO 2-1 and N2D+ 3-2 lines which are important for our science case. The spectral averaging is increased on the CO 2-1 line since we are only searching for large velocity outflows (> few km/s). The 12m array is a prefect instrument to filter out large scale CO 2-1 emission and "see" small spatial variations due to outflows from any embedded sources.
Baseband4 centered at 223.8 GHz does not contain any strong lines that are central to our science case. In order to reduce the data rate, we have used a single spectral window to act as a continuum baseband. Since these objects are starless clump candidates, we do not anticipate significant contamination from lines in this band.

The angular resolution requested in this survey of 0.8 arcseconds permits us to resolve the thermal Jeans length by more than a factor of two for the most distant source (4.8 kpc) in our sample. This requires a slightly extended configuration. This angular resolution is equivalent to the resolution used in the Zhang et al. (2015) cycle 0 observations (Fig 1). Since a primary goal is to study the core mass function, it is important to resolve individual cores; this cannot be achieved reliably in the most compact configuration at 1.3mm.
Since the emission for these sources is extended, ACA observations are required to bridge the spacings between single dish continuum observations (Fig. 2) and the 12m array. For all of the sources in this sample, we have continuum images at resolutions down to at least 20" (i.e. 870 micron from ATALASGAL or our own 1.2mm IRAM NIKA observations with 11" resolution for most sources). We have set the largest angular extent to 20" in the OT since we have information on the large scale mass distribution on scales slightly smaller than this already. This means that we are requesting ACA 7m array observations but not total power observations for this proposal. Zhang et al. (2015) also did not use ACA total power measurements and successfully measured the core mass function as well as virial parameters in the cores. For spectral line observations of outflow tracers, we want the interferometer to filter out the large scale emission (i.e. CO 2-1).

Our 1.3mm spectral line setup is based on the the successful cycle 0 setup of Zhang et al. (2015) with three modifications. First, we use targeted spectral windows that overlap the most scientifically interesting spectral lines (DCO+, SiO, CH3OH, H2CO, C18O, CO, N2D+) and employ dual polarization. Second, instead of uniform spectral resolution in all 4 basebands, we have increased the spectral resolution in baseband 2 covering the H2CO lines so that we have better velocity resolution (0.4 km/s) on the brightest dense gas tracer (see Fig. 3 of Zhang et al. 2015). Third, in order to reduce the data rate, the fourth baseband (center 233.82 GHz), which does not contain any significant lines of scientific interest, is switched to a continuum setting.
The published ALMA observations of Zhang et al. (2015) provide a direct guide to the observed line strengths and rms level required for our proposal to be successful. For 1.3mm continuum observations, the criteria we require is that we have a line-free continuum sensitivity of less than 50 uJy/beam. This permits us to detect cores in the continuum down to a mass limit of less than 0.5 solar masses at 6-sigma for the most distant source in our sample (4.8 kpc which incidentally is also the same ditance as the source observed in Zhang et al. 2015). The mass limit is calculated assuming OH opacities and the median observed temperature of 12K toward this sample of starless clump candidates (GBT NH3 observations; Svoboda et al., in prep.). In the OT, we have listed the peak flux density (scaled from 1.1mm single dish images) so that the OT may calculate a S/N, but the real criteria for our proposal is a continuum rms level < 50 uJy/beam set by a scientifically interesting mass limit. Note that Zhang et al. only included 3 basebands in their continuum due a problem with one baseband. Our final continuum sensitivity is better despite having slightly less continuum bandwidth because we are using dual polarization (they used single polarization).
Zhang et al. (2015) reached a sensitivity of 2.5 mJy with a channel spacing of 488.3 kHz. Since the lines that we are most interested in studying (H2CO, DCO+, N2D+, SiO, CO, etc.) have strengths of at least a few 10s of mJy toward the starless sources in the cycle 0 observations (Q. Zhang, priv. comm.) and we are targeting starless candidates, we request an rms that will give us at least 5-sigma rms detections in the most important lines. In order to decrease the total observing time, we have increased the spectral line rms to 3 mJy for this proposal (2.5 mJy results in 11 hours of 12m array time vs. only 7.2 hours at 3 mJy); this change will not affect our science goals. For this sample of starless clump candidates, the average NH3 (1,1) linewidth from GBT observations is 2.6 km/s (Svoboda et al., in prep.); our spectral resolution is sufficient to resolve the linewidth. We are requesting that the spectral windows centered on the H2CO lines (which are expected to be among the strongest dense gas tracers in our setup) have a higher spectral resolution of 282 kHz (0.39 km/s) to facilitate better kinematic studies than the original Zhang et al. setup. The 0.7 - 0.8 km/s resolution for other lines is sufficient to study their distribution as well as search for outflows from previously undetected protostellar sources in the lines of CO 2-1 and SiO 5-4.
In summary, the spectral line rms criteria of 3 mJy for 560 kHz channel widths simultaneously satisfies our continuum rms critera. The OT estimates a continuum sensitivity of 34 uJy in 4.219 GHz of bandwidth (N.B. we shall use line free channels, so the actual continuum bandwidth is slightly reduced). We shall attempt self-cal of continuum emission (as was done by Zhang et al.) and apply the gain solution to the spectral line data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: By combining observations and catalogs from recent Galactic plane mid-infrared, far-infrared, (sub)millimeter, radio, and maser surveys, we have identified over 2500 massive starless clump candidates that lack evidence of current star formation in the 15 < l < 55 range of the first quadrant. This population of clumps represents the future sites of intermediate and high-mass star formation in the Galaxy and are excellent targets to obtain observational constraints on the initial conditions for clump fragmentation and intermediate/high-mass star formation. We propose to observe a sample of 12 of the most massive starless clump candidates (M ~ 500 - 4000 Msun) within 5kpc with ALMA at 1.3mm to study the physical and kinematical properties of individual starless cores. This survey will systematically characterize the core mass function and fragmentation down to 0.5 solar masses and 0.03pc scales while simultaneously constraining the virial parameter and kinematic structure of these regions. Deuterated species within the bandpass shall identify cores that are very cold and dense and that may be on the cusp of star formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: The PI (Y. Shirley) also has a cycle 2 proposal in the queue (2013.1.00967.S)
